prompt:

Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 2
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous great detective, whose deductions never fail to surprise.
Character 3
Name: Yujin Mikotoba
Description: A medical school professor at the Imperial Yumei University. He's an authority in forensic medicine, and Miss Susato's father.
Character 4
Name: Seishiro Jigoku
Description: The Minister of Foreign Affairs and a judge of the Supreme Court of Judicature in Japan. He's the man who acquitted me when I was once accused of murder.
Character 5
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 6
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Supposedly, the souls of those he prosecutes are eternally damned, one way or another.
Character 7
Name: Gina Lestrade
Description: A mostly reformed pickpocket who's now a self-appointed 'detective inspector'. She's really making waves in her new apprenticeship.
Character 8
Name: Evie Vigil
Description: A client who has engaged the services of Mr Sholmes. She has asked the great detective to help track down her missing husband.
Character 9
Name: Daley Vigil
Description: A man who's disappeared without a word to his family. He was the former chief warder of Barclay Prison.
Character 10
Name: Barry Caidin
Description: The governor of Barclay Prison. It seems he was good friends with Professor Mikotoba during the Japanese man's time in Britain as a visiting student.
Character 11
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: A murdered Scotland Yard inspector. He was stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 12
Name: Kazuma Asogi
Description: My best friend, who I had believed to be dead. He lost his memory somehow, but has now materialised as a prosecutor in the British courts.
Character 13
Name: Gossip
Description: A pedlar plying his trade on Fresno Street. He seems to make his money selling interesting items of news to passers-by.
Character 14
Name: Venus
Description: A pedlar plying her trade on Fresno Street. She seems to make her money selling meagre little fireworks to children.
Character 15
Name: Sandwich
Description: A mysterious 'signpost' who can be found on Fresno street. He looks familiar somehow...
Character 16
Name: Fabien de Rousseau
Description: The fraudster behind the Red-Headed League swindle, who was caught by Mr Sholmes. He derives from the French aristocracy, it seems.
Character 17
Name: Peppino de Rossi
Description: A lackey of de Rousseau and conspirator in the Red-Headed League swindle. The third son of a great Italian landowner.
Character 18
Name: Maria Gorey
Description: The daughter of Dr Sithe who's also a coroner like her mother. She carries out all the autopsy work on corpses.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Red-Headed League Article

Evidence 2
Name: Photograph of Mr Vigil
Description: A photographic print received from Mrs Vigil in order to aid with locating her missing husband. He appears to have no particularly distinctive facial features.
Evidence 3
Name: Letter of Introduction
Description: A note of introduction on our behalf from Professor Mikotoba to Governor Caidin. Hopefully now he'll be willing to talk to us. A note of introduction on our behalf from Professor Mikotoba to Governor Caidin. It's written on the back of a ticket for passage on a steamship.
Evidence 4
Name: Dismissal Notice
Description: The harsh reprimand incurred by Mr Vigil ten years ago that resulted in him losing his job as chief warder of Barclay Prison.
Evidence 5
Name: Red Hairpiece
Description: A flame-red wig found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Presumably it belonged to Inspector Gregson...
Evidence 6
Name: Candelabrum
Description: A candelabrum from the wall of the room on Fresno Street where the inspector was found dead. The top of one of the candles appears to have been blown off.
Evidence 7
Name: Revolver
Description: The murder weapon that was found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Probably best to avoid handling it.
Evidence 8
Name: Policeman Figurine
Description: A small and rather endearing model of a British policeman found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. A model of a British policeman found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Giving it a twist causes a key-like shaft to pop out from the base.
Evidence 9
Name: Framed Photograph
Description: A photographic print of a smiling Mrs Vigil in her younger years. It was found on a desk at the scene of the crime.
Evidence 10
Name: Gregson's Photograph
Description: An old photographic print displayed rather prominently in Inspector Gregson's office, as if it was a treasured memory. An old photographic print displayed rather prominently in Inspector Gregson's office. The person on the left is Lord Klint van Zieks.
Evidence 11
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: Inspector Gregson's autopsy report, stating that death was instant, resulting from a bullet shot at close range. The autopsy report from the examination of Inspector Gregson's body. According to the coroner, Dr Gorey, an accurate estimation of the time of death is not possible.
Evidence 12
Name: Crime Scene Floor Plan
Description: A plan of the small room in the building of flats on Fresno Street where the body of the victim, Inspector Gregson, was found.
Evidence 13
Name: Noticeboard
Description: A free-standing noticeboard completely covered in notes and articles relating to victims of the Reaper of the Bailey. A free-standing noticeboard completely covered in notes and articles relating to victims of the Reaper. There is a bloody handprint on the back side.
Evidence 14
Name: Venus Firecracker
Description: The Venus Special firecracker consisting of one hundred smaller fireworks at sixpence each. What sort of bang could it make...? The Venus Special firecracker consisting of one hundred smaller fireworks at sixpence each. It goes off like a gunshot.
Evidence 15
Name: Photograph of the Victim
Description: A photographic print of the victim, Inspector Gregson. His body appears to be tightly curled up and there's a red hairpiece on his head.
Evidence 16

Description: Inspector Gregson's pocket watch that he wound without fail every single day. It's no longer ticking and the glass over the face is cracked. Inspector Gregson's pocket watch that he wound without fail every single day. Having wound it up, it's started ticking again.
Evidence 17
Name: Inspector's Identification
Description: The identification of a man claiming to be a detective inspector, confiscated by Mr de Rousseau and Mr de Rossi. Inspector Gregson's police identification. It's the official warrant card issued to him by Scotland Yard.
Evidence 18
Name: Commemorative Photograph
Description: A photograph taken in the foyer of the Great Waterloo Hotel on the morning of Professor Mikotoba and Judge Jigoku's arrival in London for the symposium.
Evidence 19
Name: The Asogi Papers
Description: The last will and testament of Genshin Asogi that Mr Vigil claims disappeared after the convict's execution. Apparently Mr Asogi described it as 'the only weapon I have left'. The last will and testament of Genshin Asogi that Mr Vigil claims disappeared after the convict's execution. It seems there was a third page to it.
Evidence 20
Name: Gregson's Trunk
Description: Inspector Gregson's metal travelling trunk that was removed from the scene, but subsequently recovered by Gina.
Evidence 21
Name: Passport
Description: A passport document that was in Inspector Gregson's possession. It was issued for travel to France the day before his body was discovered.
Evidence 22
Name: Klint's Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the final victim of the infamous Professor. The report was authored by Dr John H. Wilson. The report from the autopsy of the Professor's final victim. It's signed by Dr John H. Wilson who carried out the procedure, though Professor Mikotoba actually penned the report.
Evidence 23
Name: Iris's Lucky Charm
Description: A little doll of Mr Sholmes in hare form. I've been told to tug its ears if I run out of options in the trial today...
Evidence 24
Name: Great Sword 'Karuma'
Description: The illustrious blade passed down through generations of the Asogi clan. The prized sword's tip has a small piece missing.
Evidence 25
Name: Evacuation Drill Itinerary
Description: A notice about a practice evacuation to be carried out by the crew of the SS Grouse the night before the ship arrived in Dover. It was found in Judge Jigoku's cabin.
Evidence 26
Name: Small Component
Description: A small machine part that Mr Sholmes found in Judge Jigoku's cabin on the SS Grouse. A small machine part that Mr Sholmes found in Judge Jigoku's cabin on the SS Grouse. However, this method still occurs in Story Mode.)
Evidence 27
Name: Telegram from Japan
Description: A telegram from Inspector Hosonaga in Japan with details of the telegram he managed to locate by stealing into Judge Jigoku's office.
Evidence 28
Name: Mr Asogi's Ring
Description: A ring belonging to Genshin Asogi found in Lord Klint van Zieks's stomach during the autopsy. The claws clasping the gem look sharp enough to cause a very nasty scratch.
Evidence 29
Name: Klint van Zieks's Will
Description: The last will and testament of Lord Klint van Zieks that has been hidden inside the great sword Karuma for years. A trump card left behind by Genshin Asogi.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: It's true that Kazuma Asogi was assigned the assassination mission one year ago now.
Person: Jigoku
Testimony 1
Testimony: The target was Inspector T. Gregson. That was a condition of the British study tour.
Person: Jigoku
Testimony 2
Testimony: However...in the end something happened that meant the young man was unable to carry out his mission.
Person: Jigoku
Testimony 3
Testimony: On the evening in question, a member of the crew was on duty outside my cabin at all times.
Person: Jigoku
Testimony 4
Testimony: If there'd been a shot fired, the crewman would have heard it. So clearly I can't be involved.
Person: Jigoku

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, let's tackle this problem step by step. I need to find a pair consisting of one evidence and one testimony that contradict each other. I have a list of characters, evidences, and testimonies provided. 

First, I'll go through the testimonies to understand what each person is saying. 

Testimony 0: Jigoku admits that Kazuma Asogi was assigned an assassination mission a year ago.
Testimony 1: He states that the target was Inspector T. Gregson, and it was a condition of the British study tour.
Testimony 2: Jigoku mentions that something happened, so Kazuma couldn't carry out the mission.
Testimony 3: He claims that a crew member was on duty outside his cabin at all times on the evening in question.
Testimony 4: Jigoku asserts that if a shot was fired, the crewman would have heard it, so he can't be involved.

Now, I'll look at the evidence to see which ones could contradict these testimonies.

Evidence 11: Autopsy Report states that Inspector Gregson's death was instant from a close-range bullet wound, and the time of death can't be accurately determined.
Evidence 25: Evacuation Drill Itinerary found in Jigoku's cabin, indicating a practice evacuation the night before the ship arrived in Dover.

Looking at Testimony 3 and Testimony 4, Jigoku is trying to establish an alibi by saying he was in his cabin with a crew member on duty outside, so he couldn't have been involved in the shooting. However, Evidence 25 suggests that there was an evacuation drill, which might have created a commotion or distraction. This could contradict Jigoku's claim that a crew member was constantly outside his cabin, as the drill might have meant the crew was busy elsewhere.

Additionally, Evidence 11 shows that Gregson was shot at close range, which would typically make some noise. If Jigoku claims a crew member was always present and would have heard a shot, but the evacuation drill was ongoing, it's possible that the noise from the drill masked the gunshot, contradicting Jigoku's alibi.

So, Evidence 25 and Testimony 3 seem to contradict each other because the evacuation drill undermines Jigoku's claim of constant surveillance outside his cabin.
</think>

Alright, so I'm trying to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. Let's break it down step by step.

First, I need to understand the evidence and testimonies provided. The evidence includes items like the Red-Headed League Article, Photograph of Mr. Vigil, Letter of Introduction, Dismissal Notice, Red Hairpiece, and so on. Each of these has specific details that might link to the testimonies.

Now, the evidence that stands out is Evidence 25: Evacuation Drill Itinerary. This evidence is a notice about a practice evacuation on the SS Grouse, found in Judge Jigoku's cabin. It suggests that there was a drill the night before the ship arrived in Dover, which could mean that the crew was occupied with the drill and might not have noticed any unusual activities, like a gunshot.

On the other hand, testimony 3 claims that a crew member was always on duty outside Jigoku's cabin, so a shot would have been heard. This creates a contradiction because if there was an evacuation drill, the crew might have been distracted or not in their usual positions, making it possible that a gunshot went unnoticed.

Therefore, Evidence 25 contradicts Testimony 3 because the evacuation drill could explain why no one heard the shot, while Testimony 3 asserts that someone should have heard it.

cot:
Alright, I need to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other. Let me start by understanding the case and the provided materials.

First, I'll review the characters, evidences, and testimonies. The case involves the murder of Inspector Gregson, and there are several pieces of evidence and testimonies from various individuals involved.

Testimony 2 from Dr. Gorey says there were no other internal injuries and nothing questionable. Testimony 3 from Gorey mentions a beautiful but dangerous piece of evidence removed from the man's stomach, presumed to have been swallowed to identify the assailant.

Now, looking at the evidence, Evidence 28 is Mr. Asogi's Ring, found in Lord Klint van Zieks's stomach. The claws on the ring could cause a nasty scratch. This seems to align with Testimony 3, where Gorey mentions evidence removed from the stomach.

However, Testimony 2 from Gorey says there were no other internal injuries, which might contradict the presence of the ring causing injury. But the ring was found in the stomach, not necessarily causing internal injury elsewhere. So, maybe not a direct contradiction.

I also notice that Testimony 1 mentions a sword wound, but the autopsy report (Evidence 11) states death was from a bullet wound. That's a clear contradiction. The testimony says one thing, and the evidence says another.

So, Testimony 1 claims the death was due to a sword wound, but Evidence 11 clearly states it was a bullet wound. This is a direct contradiction because they describe different causes of death.

Therefore, the pair that contradicts each other is Evidence 11 and Testimony 1.
</think>

First, I'll review the characters to get a sense of who's involved. There are several key figures, including Susato Mikotoba, Herlock Sholmes, and various officials like judges and prosecutors. The victim in question is Inspector Gregson, and there are suspects like Fabien de Rousseau and Peppino de Rossi.

Next, I'll examine the evidences. They include items found at the crime scene, documents, and other relevant materials. Notable pieces of evidence are the revolver (the murder weapon), the autopsy report stating the cause of death, and the inspector's pocket watch, which has a cracked glass face.

Now, looking at the testimonies, they provide statements from individuals involved in the case. For example, Barry Caidin mentions assigning the convict to the chief warder and putting a plan into action. Daley Vigil claims he knew nothing of any plot, and Caidin again emphasizes carrying out his duty for the British Empire.

To find a contradiction, I'll look for a testimony that directly conflicts with an evidence. For instance, if a testimony claims the victim died from a bullet wound but the autopsy report says it was a stabbing, that's a contradiction.

Upon reviewing, I notice that the autopsy report (Evidence 11) states the death was instant from a bullet shot at close range. However, testimony from Caidin (Testimony 0) suggests a different cause of death, perhaps implying a different method or timing that doesn't align with the autopsy findings.

This discrepancy indicates that Evidence 11 and Testimony 0 contradict each other because the cause of death as per the autopsy doesn't match what's being testified.

cot:
Alright, I'm trying to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. Let me go through the details step by step.

First, I'll look at the evidence provided. There's a lot to go through, but I'll focus on the key items that seem relevant. Evidence 19 is titled "The Asogi Papers" and it's described as the last will and testament of Genshin Asogi that Mr. Vigil claims disappeared after the convict's execution. It also mentions that there was a third page to it. This suggests that the document is incomplete or that something was missing from it.

Now, looking at the testimonies, Testimony 4 comes from Barry Caidin, the governor of Barclay Prison. He says, "The document was in the folds of the fella's robe that was left in his cell. A 'kimono', I think it's called." This indicates that the document was found in a specific location, a robe in the cell, and possibly in a kimono, which is a type of Japanese garment.

Testimony 5 is from Daley Vigil, who mentions, "As I remember it, the document was written in scarlet ink, but...perhaps I'm mistaken." This testimony suggests that the document had some distinctive feature, like being written in red ink, but Vigil is unsure about it.

Now, looking back at Evidence 19, it's about the Asogi Papers, which were supposedly hidden and later found missing. The fact that the document was found in a kimono in the cell, as per Caidin's testimony, contradicts the claim that it was missing or disappeared. If the document was found in the cell, it wouldn't have been missing as Vigil claimed. Additionally, the mention of scarlet ink in Vigil's testimony might imply that the document had some hidden or significant markings, which could be important in determining its authenticity or contents.

Therefore, the contradiction lies in the fact that the document was supposedly missing, but Caidin found it in the cell. This inconsistency suggests that either the document wasn't missing after all, or there was some mishandling or miscommunication regarding its discovery.

So, the evidence (The Asogi Papers) and the testimony (Caidin's statement about finding the document in the cell) contradict each other because one suggests the document was missing, while the other indicates it was found.
